measured_by: Delay Discounting Task (choices between smaller-sooner and larger-later monetary rewards)
justification: "…the extent to which an individual makes decisions that provide instant gratification … can be measured using delay discounting tasks."
The paper lists the TSST as a standardised protocol "used to experimentally induce acute stress" in the studies included in the meta-analysis.
"The Cold Pressor Task (CPT… has been shown to elicit a … stress response…" indicating it is employed as a measure/induction of acute stress.
"Several stress induction protocols have aimed to combine physical and psychological elements, such as the Maastricht Acute Stress Test (MAST; Smeets et al., 2012)."
The manuscript names the "Mannheim Multicomponent Stress Test (MMST; Kolotylova et al., 2009)" as another protocol for inducing/measuring acute stress.
The inclusion criteria mention the "social evaluative Cold Pressor Task (SECPT)" among tasks that manipulate acute stress.
Studies had to use an acute stress manipulation such as "…psychosocial stressor (e.g., Trier Social Stress Test (TSST), Montreal Imaging Stress Task (MIST))…".
The previous meta-analysis is described as including studies where stress was "operationalized by self-reported questionnaire data, such as the Perceived Stress Scale (Cohen et al., 1983)."
The article notes that earlier work used "the Life Stress Checklist (Wolfe & Kimerling, 1997)" to quantify life stress experiences.
